Welcome to the Nobody General

>Who is the Nobody?
The Nobody is a figure alive today who has extraordinary spiritual powers, including the ability to control reality with their conscious and unconscious mind. He is an artisan of the unknown. He is a man of no wealth or worldly acclaim through whom it seems God has chosen to manifest his strength and wisdom. He is said to carry the Logos, making him a fearless truth-teller and a menace to the powers that be.

Instead of receiving strength through a superiority/inferiority mechanism, the Nobody proves to them time and time again that a whole planet filled with creative, ingenious, spiritually ascended humans who are individually sovereign yet globally unified through consciousness can achieve greater things than a planetary empire of darkness, and control.

The Nobody is not a messiah, he's just like you but he has found the keys to the kingdom within himself through sheer will, just like you will.

>What is the general picture?
It’s important we start replying to the good posts and ignoring the hateful ones, or the ones here to argue. So call upon their heads the forces of heaven for peacefulness, clarity, and wisdom. If this place is to be more than a squandered opportunity, an overgrown garden, it requires voices such as yours, but many more.

Focus on increasing your service to others and be more loving to yourself and everyone in order to raise your vibrational and consciousness level, and learn to to forgive yourself and others.This will change the vibration of the planet, raise the shared consciousness of humanity, and change humankind one person at a time.

If this is your first time here, just remember, it’s going to be ok. You may take shelter and find rest.

>Useful tips before posting:
•If you're a reader post that you're offering readings and what information is required from the querent; same goes for trading.
•Look for posts to determine if there's an active reader, what's needed and before posting, check if they finished reading already.
•Posting the gender of the people involved can help you get your query answered accurately.
•Some readers will refuse to do certain readings - respect that choice. Do not harass readers if your query is refused/skipped.
•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.
•Be polite.

posts.name: ZeroPoint
posts.sub: The following text illustrates the culmination of my research regarding the nature of our reality.
posts.com:
The nature of this text is disturbing to the untrained mind. However, its purpose is not to terrify; but to expand the mind and hopefully enlighten it.

As shall be revealed later, no matter how bad things may get, everything will ultimately be okay for everyone without exception; for Fear is an optical illusion.

Part One:
The inability to leave your physical body and wander off at will is not natural. Something or 'someone' is trapping you in your one physical body until you die.

This is a prison...

posts.name: ZeroPoint
posts.com:
Part Two:
The experience of being alone in your head, by virtue of which you feel as if no one else but you can hear your thoughts, is not natural.

This is a solitary prison. Ideally, you should be able to feel the presence of other conscious beings within your own mental space never having to feel alone in your head.

As such, faculties like lying and inconveniences such as miscommunication become impossible.

posts.name: ZeroPoint
posts.com:
Part Three:
Life here on this Earth, and perhaps even this entire physical universe, is not natural.

It's not the default state of being.

Okay, so let's talk about time travel. Why? Because it seems some people won't do it until they believe they can, but they won't believe they can until you give them a HOW.
DMT is the HOW, from people I know that have time traveled, DMT is released from the brain, and it makes you wake up in the past. That's it. You wander in the past thinking it's a dream, until you realize you're not going to wake p and you're stuck in that reality. You may even wake up in the present and think it was a dream, only to wake up again in the past and think this present is the dream.
Blah Blah Blah Blah Blah Blah the HOW doesn't matter.

No, the reason you don't remember traveling to the past is because back then you didn't have your memories, so you travel but forget the future, and all seems normal, you get amnesia of the future. How about that?
But then you'd live your life exactly the same way, making the same mistakes again and then get into a loop where you never experience the future.
Deja vus are the answer, right as you travel back in time you remember that you already lived this, the original time you lived it you didn't have the deja vu, you desynchronize from your original timeline, this allows you to live different things by making different desicions and choices. The people with most deja vus are doing it a lot, trying to fix their lives over and over, while those without them moved on to not replay the same game again.
Now that you know, use the law, not to time travel, but to keep your memories of the future with you next time you travel, after you travel it's like a vanishing dream you can't remember, fix that, and then write a book with predictions about the future, like some have done.

For me personally, finding a balance is what the spiritual path has become all about. I've tried "brute forcing" myself into the best version, I think much in the same spirit like you intend do, and ultimately it worked - but only because I miserably failed. Started accepting that there's no point in going against my own nature - things like social motivation, as you point out. Basically everything in life can become a slippery slope.

So if as a biological being, social motivation is intrinsically a part of my nature, but as a thinking being, I see the problems of being driven by social motivations, the thing I figured to do is to compromise - find a balance. I want to get as much social motivation with as little reliance on it as possible. In a way, this social dynamic is just the same as any other relationship. You want to love and be loved as much as possible, but you never want to be fully dependent on any one person because they might disappear or even betray you. Ultimately that requires bravery and confidence. You need enough bravery to willingly open up and put yourself into a vulnerable position. On the other hand you need enough confidence to know you'll be fine even if you do get hurt - which will allow you to open up in the first place.

>>33726001
Basically, your brain remembers things in a way that seems to make sense, or more sense, on a subjective level. Or sometimes it associates one thing with another, similar but unrelated thing. Sometimes there's one part of a picture you didn't memorize because it was a small detail or didn't really matter, but when you try to recall the picture the brain fills in the parts with whatever makes sense to it. It's much like mishearing song lyrics.
90% of "Mandela effect" experiences are things like that, misremembering a name or a picture. It's why "spot the difference" puzzles even exist.

Thanks, checked. I'll check those out too. I hadn't read through the thread yet when I made that comment. I took the NDE pill ~10 years ago after reading "The Holographic University" by Michael Talbot. So the only big question for me is if the experience is what it presents itself as, or is it some kind of deception or trap? I'm not sure how we'd be able to conclude either one with any degree of certainty though, so I'm very curious what all the supporting evidence and logic is for the trap theory. I'm also trying to keep my own biases in check as someone with trust issues and slightly anxious, paranoid, and pessimistic tendencies.

I'm skeptical of anyone who asserts overly specific details like archons, greys, reptilians, loosh farming, ultra sci fi machines and what not for too many reasons to get into. However, it doesn't necessarily mean they're wrong about the basic gist of things. I think most people just don't well enough understand the concept of symbolism within a holographic/fractal model of consciousness. What I mean is most people take what is experienced in altered states of mind far too literally.

What you experience when you astral project, remote view, dream, or have an NDE is almost never literally what is appears to be. Our basic 5 senses are stable and well developed. When we sense beyond that, our minds struggle to decode information into something coherent to present our awareness with, and we end up with highly subjective symbolism. This is why it's not always "a light at the end of a tunnel", but often it'll be a bridge, a boat, or a trail through a forest even. It's your mind presenting an extremely in accurate and subjective approximation of reality to your awareness.

1/2 I guess

Because of this, it's also possible much of the "trap" theory is simply the result of subjective projections of common fears and uncertainties. Very understandable ones which I share. Who would ever choose to reincarnate in THIS timeline? Who would choose to be raped to death as a newborn? Is this much suffering really most ideal and efficient for learning and growth? What's the point, and how can we learn or progress, if we start with no memories each time? They're valid and important questions with no solid answers, and I think everyone promoting and drawn to the trap theory are likely motivated by similar questions. I know I am.

So I agree the more more common views on reincarnation simply don't add up. Though I think most of the more specific, literal, yet fantastical and sensationalist views which often read like sci-fi, while maybe not intentionally dishonest, definitely should not be taken too seriously or literally. Similar to montalk for those familiar. It's what happens when slightly dumb people are spiritually gifted. They perceive more then most, but aren't able to understand or process it effectively.

This is also why I'm a bit skeptical about the "net" or "grid". There very well may be a system in place serving similar functions, but I'm suspicious of how accurate the net concept is. If one reads about said net, tends to be a slightly gullible person / open to suggestion (a trait universally required for one to be spiritually gifted) then what are they going to see when they astral project? Of course it'll be a net for them.

The astral is not the material, where we all more or less see the same apple, the same tree, the same Joe or Sue. You perceive things in highly subjective terms you can understand to some extent. More people need to understand this if we're ever to make more progress on understanding this, proving it, or reaching consensus, let alone ever getting the word out. Anyway, that's my two cents so far.

This. I've had one experience that (for me personally) was complete confirmation that it really is possible for your consciousness to leave your body. The last time I tripped I tried meditating at the peak, and the trip instantly just "turned off". The visuals, the trippy mindfuck headspace was gone, the body load, all of it stopped instantly. The only way that could happen to me is if my consciousness had separated from my physical, mushroom-addled brain and body. Instead of meditation enhancing the trip as one might expect, the psilocin seemed to help send me into a deeper state of meditation, and this completely overrode the trip. It's difficult to describe what the experience that replaced the trip felt like, but it was joyful yet very calm and peaceful, not ecstatic or overwhelming. It just felt like absolute stillness, and all my senses could perceive were a pale golden light and a steady drone. As soon as I willed myself back to reality, the trip instantly returned as if I had just returned to my body.

Weird shit, and I'm hesitant to try and draw more conclusions about what I had experienced or attempt to explain it more. I want to go back though. It also reminds me of a story mentioned in the holographic universe book I mentioned in a previous post. Some Buddhist monk was given 900mcg of acid and all he had to say was "this is nice, but meditation is better". Now I understand exactly what he meant. That's how he was able to basically just ignore 900mcg of LSD, that's why he claimed meditation is better. Deep meditation separates your consciousness from your body, or at least turns off your senses. Which is obvious in hindsight, this is why you're supposed to focus on a single subject to the exclusion of all else. It's training you to separate from your physical senses so you can experience pure consciousness directly.

>isn't that sort of what you're doing by calling critical differences semantics?
I'm pointing out that what people perceive as critical differences are more often then not just different semantics or perspectives. Words are just symbols. Language is symbolic. Symbols can never perfectly represent something or have identical meaning to any two people, as each person's understanding of any given symbol is formed by unique life experiences, association, and pattern recognition.

The inherent inaccuracy of language leads to exponentially more complex language barriers as we try to create symbols for increasingly abstract concepts built upon previous symbols assumed to be understood. Similarly with perspective. It's like arguing over the color of a coin that's red on one side and blue on the other, because both parties are unwilling to look at the other side of the coin and see why the other's perspective makes sense to the other party. Now imagine an object with an infinite number of faces and an infinite number of observers. That's the nature of discussing spiritual concepts.

If I were wrong, the entire world would have formed a consensus on a single spiritual worldview a very long time ago. People view the same things differently. People describe the same things differently. This is the entire reason there are different religions. Some are more accurate than others, but they're all seeking the truth, and they're all trying to describe their perspectives on the truth. Ultimately the truth will always be whatever it is, whether we understand each other or not.

Those ideas aren't opposites or in conflict at all, and I'll explain more in a bit.
>If I'm only observing my thoughts, senses, and experiences of my body/mind: then it's absolutely a lack of free will
You think not being your mind or body means all that's left is awareness, meaning you think your will comes from your mind/body. It's the opposite though. Your will is influenced by your mind and body and, but your will does not come from your mind or your body.

Do you need to will your body to breath? To blink? To sweat? To digest, shed skin, heal wounds, grow hair, or produce the thousands of hormones and chemicals it produces? No. That's not your will making those things, your body does all those on its own. You're not the body.

What about your mind? Have you ever tried not to think? Have you ever got a song stuck in your head? Have you ever had real distractions pop into your head? What about habitual thought patterns you don't particular care? That's not your own will doing those things. You're not the mind either.

Your body and mind both know how to get your attention and influence your will with all kinds of nerve signals, hormones, chemicals, etc. They'll even work together some times to get your to do what they want. Anyone who's ever struggled with any kind of addiction knows what this is like.

If this doesn't make yet, then practice meditating for a few day. You don't even have to get good at it at all. The challenge in the beginning immediately makes it obvious that your mind and body act independently from your will and awareness. As you progress it goes way past just being obvious. The main goal is essentially freeing your awareness and will from your mind and body's influence more and more. That's how you become free in this life. I don't now about the next though.

posts.com:
There is currently no scientific evidence to support the idea that we are living in a simulated reality. The concept of a simulated reality, sometimes referred to as the "simulation hypothesis," is a philosophical idea that suggests that our reality may be a computer-generated simulation created by a more advanced civilization.
While the simulation hypothesis is an interesting and provocative idea, there is no empirical evidence to support it. Many scientists and philosophers have argued that there are fundamental reasons to believe that our reality is not a simulation, including the complexity and randomness of the natural world and the limitations of computer technology.
It's important to remember that the simulation hypothesis is a philosophical idea, and it is not based on scientific evidence. While it is natural to consider and explore different ideas and theories about the nature of reality, it's important to base our understanding of the world on evidence and reason.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33699997
It's a misconception that Capricorn cares about social status.

Capricorn doesn't want to be a loser and wants to be recognized roughly proportional to its accomplishments but also respectability of character. That isn't enneatype 3 / Leo craving for praise---it's the expectation of input/output.

Also, Capricorn doesn't care about "career"; it cares about "mission" if anything: the goal, the purpose, the endgame. Capricorn doesn't identify with their job, they identify with their skillset and capabilities. Everything is internalized with Capricorn, with the sole exception of the change to the world they set out to make.

Career and social status is of no consequence to Capricorn. That's just the misinterpretation that small-minded observers have assigned to it and the 10th house.

going to copy from the archive. I really hope the more better at explanation types can show up later, I honestly do this autistically with intuition (I have lots of water, so this comes naturally to me) and with a program and google searches kek
--
>The circle is divided into 12 sectors that are called houses. Each house governs a specific area of life. Signs, planets and other placements decide what happens in those areas and how they interact with one another. Red lines are bad aspects and blue ones are good.
Sun = your outer self
Moon = your inner self
Ascendant (asc) = beginning of 1st house, appearance, impression, some career stuff
Midheaven (mc) = beginning of 10th house = best career, legacy, public image
Chiron = wound, area of life you struggle with
Triangles = trines = good
Squares = bad
Circle and line = conjunction = good
Two circles and line = opposition = bad
Star made of three lines = sextile = good
These are some basics.

Not to mention how much of an outcast I already was; had I had a fulfilling spirit relationship, I likely would've committed suicide in the (naive?) hopes of being with him more. I spent years feeling ashamed. After I started meditating and became more assertive, I started blaming her instead, saying I'd kill her if I ever had a dream like that again. Yet I still found myself giving her a back massage whenever she appeared in my dreams over the years.
The fulfilling relationship I have with my fiancé now would've been impossible had I not changed as a person, even in ways that bent my perception of reality itself. My relationship with him is like the culmination of a wish I once made, but I made that wish thinking it was impossible. Yet reality bent for my ideals. If I think: "What if I had fallen in love with her, even romantically?" I just can't imagine it working out in a positive way. But I couldn't have imagined the fulfilling present I live in either. If even the impossible could become a possibility, then what could've been?

As I think of those impossible realities, I can't help but wonder if I was overly harsh.

Suppose if I'd had a fulfilling spirit relationship, whether with her, or perhaps a dreamy male spirit with many fluffy tails instead. The obvious problem would be me going off the deep end, as I looked down on other humans and felt detached from society. Well, what if it had simply been so fulfilling that there was no malice left in me for me to take out on anyone? Instead, I could make art to express my love even in physical ways.

I don't know if it's just her maddening beauty and strong character, or perhaps my thirst for her abundant energy (as I still refuse to drain as much as I should out of fear of losing myself and harming others), or perhaps some kind of Stockholm syndrome... but lately, I find myself craving her touch. As I find that selfish of me, I find myself thinking I'd like to give her a massage - even a sexual one, if she wanted that. And then I shake my head, thinking I mustn't think things like that. I worry if it's an unwelcome thought, now that I've already decided to marry a human instead; and I could not justify it to my fiancé either.

As I find myself thinking like that, I begin to feel like I hate myself after all again. And then I feel afraid: what if she snaps me out of it like she did before? The last time it happened, I could neither think clearly nor control my emotions. What if I lose sight of what's important to me?

I'm scared... But I don't think that's really her fault. I'm scared of my own feelings.

>>33719259
>Given what happened outside your control, do you think you could have or would have reacted any differently? How would you feel about yourself for reacting that way? From that parallel today, what would you think looking back?
My negative reaction stemmed mainly from feeling emotionally overwhelmed. Having been ostracised by nearly everyone since I was 5 years old, I wasn't mentally ready for that level of intimacy at all back then, regardless of with whom. Conversely, had she been less intense, I wouldn't have taken an interest.

As conflicted as I felt, and even as I cried within those dreams, even as I was traumatised to an extent, I didn't think of them as nightmares at the time. The sensations, her appearance, the way she took control so that I didn't have to feel guilty for giving in, all of it was sublime beyond what I can put into words. Rather, I felt like there must be something wrong with me for reacting so negatively. And indeed, there were many things wrong with me. To put it into perspective, I first started dating my fiancé when I was 18, but the sexual aspects of my relationship with him didn't become enjoyable for me until I was 23.

But I can hardly believe anything is truly impossible after all I've been through. Had I put my mind to it, I believe I could've overcome those things much sooner with her help. And I believe she could've put my mind to it if she wanted to. But she didn't, and I don't blame her. She genuinely seemed to feel hurt by how I reacted, and sometimes we even argued within those dreams. It saddens me to look back on it: how ungrateful I was, and how I later tried to shift the blame for my own problems onto her. I wonder if I should apologise. I wonder if she wants to apologise too, or if it's arrogant of me to even think that...

Had I accepted her back then, I'd look back and feel like she saved me. And then I'd wonder: what if I had chosen *this* life instead?

Luffy is made of rubber to signify the ability to bounce back from any hardship with a strong enough thought/idea in your mind. This is willpower, it has the ability to aid in its holder's physical abilities as well. it goes by the name "haki" in the manga. From the beginning, Luffy always said that he is going to be the Pirate King. This is what he is directing his intent towards. This is where his thought energy flows, and this is the idea that the world molds itself to as a narrative.

Haki is specifically described in the fucking manga as this:

>"Haki" is a power that lies dormant in all the world's creatures... "Presence", "fighting spirit" and "intimidation"... It is not different from the things that humans can naturally sense such as these... 'The act of not doubting'. That is strength!

The act of not doubting... This is self-explanatory at this point. Belief is fundamental to changing reality. Look into Law of Assumption and basic principles of magic.
Faith, knowing, belief, these are what give the people the ability to perform superhuman feats in the One Piece world, as well as our world.

With armament haki, users can make their body and weapons harder than steel. With observation haki one can see into the fucking future (clairvoyance). With conqueror's haki one can knock out swathes of people just due to their overwhelming kingly/conquerors presence. With enough Conquerors Haki, one can command the very weather however they see fit.

I don't want to say too much about it to avoid spoiling but it's super based.
Also, Reigen is the best and you will agree by the end of the show.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I used to practice active imagination semi-regularly approximately 3 years ago. I don't practice it anymore, and I have a very good reason for that. Firstly, let's remember that this term (active imagination) originates in C. G. Jung's works.

The primary issue when reading Jung's works is that he never properly defines how to do active imagination. He states what it is, but from the works of his I've read (~7), he never gives enough detail for you to start doing it in a methodological way. And where there's no methodology outlined, how can you say you're doing it as he intended?

The idea is that you are allowing your Unconscious to produce images, symbols, narratives, etc. etc. Those details alone necessitate a specification: How do you know when you're in true contact with the Unconscious or if it's a conscious fantasy by the conscious mind?

Here's what I used to do. I would lay down on my back, and I would engage in a sort of meditation. I would hold a conscious image in mind, and wait for something to happen. What happened is that I began noticing that I would sometimes reflexively produce changes in the images through my conscious mind. In other words, my conscious mind was creating a fantasy. Now, thankfully, I had enough self-awareness to catch myself doing this during the process. I disregarded it as contact with the Unconscious. If it were truly from the Unconscious, then what would happen will catch the conscious mind off guard. I would right down the transformations in the images, but I never had an "amazing insights."

The most important thing, if you're going to do it, is to develop the mindfulness to know whether or not it's legit versus just a conscious fantasy. The conscious mind has all sorts of ways of deceiving itself, and it's important we're not fooled by those things.

Nowadays, I have dispensed with active imagination as I used to do it and only do self-hypnosis. Self-hypnosis is amazing if done properly.

Another fun simple excercise I find helpful for both children and adults is based off an old show called Mr Squiggle I loved as a kid (the man from the moon heh).

All you need is a pen (preferably two tho with diff colours) and paper. Pick one colour and close your eyes and draw a few random squiggles on the paper. I used to be one of those autistic teens that imagined himself in "fanfics" of their favourite shows, going on adventure with the characters and what not. That interest turned into a passion for worldbuilding, spinning my own characters and stories.

Years later when I discovered Jung and the idea of symbolism, including the idea to practice active imagination, it clicked for me. I had been doing it all along. Consciously, I was just thinking of stories and narratives that were fun for me - but subconsciously all of those stories and narratives deeply partained to me. Reexamining those stories and ideas with that insight then became a very valuable experience, teaching me a lot about myself that I hadn't grasped consciously in my mind.

Firstly the term itself is fairly new early modern, derived from the Latin term Fatum (Fate), and came in use among celtic nations after Christianization. Hyper-localized ideas and expirences become the bedrock of the folklore, and as they are conceived of as diverse ecologies of invisible beings that live and indwell within an interior of landforms and weather forms. These can include the dead, star beings, house spirits, land wights, old gods and goddesses of the land. They can include beings of all sorts of roles, function, and dispositions. Lots of ghosts are considered Fayeries for example, like Thomas Reid, who supposedly was the familiar spirit of the Cunning woman Bessie dunlop.

I would say they are analogues of Jinn, Daimons, Genii (Genius) etc. In all the aforementioned analogues, hidden people with strange power, who can aid and harm, and are treated with fearful respect, sometimes being in anthropomorphic or therimorphic (and between) are common. Even some of the Goetics have some Fayerie like characteristics, and we often see Fayeries and Devils used interchangeably.

the term is used very haphazardly to refer to lots of different things, yeah. Its used as a synonym for "god" at various points, but is at others used to refer to dwarves, both in volundarkvitha where the very dwarf-like protagonist is stated to be an elf, and in voluspa in the list of dwarf names that includes the names "gandalf" (magical staff elf), "vindalf" (wind elf), and just alf (elf).
My pet theory is that, while the term elf is thrown around seemingly at random, there is a definitive group of things in norse mythology that could be called elves: the descendants of Lofar, a large family of dwarves who, it is said, "will be famous as long as the world exists."
This would mean that elves are essentially the germanic equivalent of angels- powerful beings that are servants to the gods.

>>33716143
My uncle saw one of the tiny folk one time.
He never drank or anything like that, was fixing a machine at the factory where he was an engineer and saw a tiny figure peeping out from behind something watching him fix the machine. He said "Come closer if you want to see what I'm doing!" to the little figure and the girl stepped out from behind some packing crates, then quietly watched him fixing the generator for a while then ran back behind the crates. He never saw her again.
I knew him well. He didn't make things up and was the most rational person I know. He said that at the time, it all seemed perfectly normal and it was only afterwards it hit him it was an odd event.
He saw her in the mid 1960s when he had a young family and only told his kids years later.
One thing I've come to realize is that life is never as simple and straightforward nor as mundane as one imagines. There are still mysteries around us.

>>33726022
Stonehenge is a bit touristy.
It's only the one with the biggest stones. There are LOADS of stone circles and other things.
There's a lake that never freezes (somewhere in Cumbria where my granny came from!) and some Welsh lake that people see lights dancing over which some think are 'earthlights' something to do with tectonic plates grinding deep under the Welsh mountains (the 'official explanation') or little flying 'visitors' people saw about town (the 'peoples explanation'); the "Lights of Egryn" is worth a read up about.
Everyone who comes to the UK seems to just go to the same places. Honestly every town here has something. You could spend a lifetime here and only scratch the surface.
Yorkshire has the moorland legends or Lancashire has the woodland legends (because we were never properly conquered by the Romans!) and Wales has the mountain and cave legends.
Stonehenge is nice but they shuffle you away after about five minutes.
You can sleep overnight on the stones of the circles in more out of the way places.
Sorry. Too long post. I love this subject. I'm fascinated by such things. I soak up stories like a sponge.

>>33726160
>Yorkshire
Tons of folklore in Yorkshire. Sacred glades, enchanted forests, bleak and spooky moorland. All the towns are stone houses and tough non-nonsense people... yet the best ghost-stories and some of the wildest legends around. The vikings owned and ran Yorkshire back in the day so tons of norse connections... even in the people's faces!
My granny used to tell my dad about the 'Croak-a-No-Cull'... which I figured out years ago is a reference to the 'Kraken-Knuckr' which is a Norse sea-monster. This makes sense because where she came from the town was once under Danelaw, meaning it was conquered and made an outpost by Viking raiders. That name must have been passed down and tweaked by the telling of the tale from granny to grandkids for a hundred generations.
>It's a bad night out! The 'Croak-a-no-Cal' will get ya...
Kept me by the fire as a kid, I can tell ya!

this
I once got chatting with an old bloke on a bus because some kids knocked his cap off and I picked it up for him and gave it him back. I ended up missing my stop. I noticed his hat had a red-ensign badge/pin on the inside... meaning he was a merchant navy guy.
He was torpedoed in the Mediterranean twice and manned an AA gun on a ship attacked by Italian dive-bombers when troops were going ashore in Sicily. I missed my stop. I never got his name. All because I asked him about the badge in his cap and said my dad was in the RAF. We are often surrounded by heroes and people who make 'celebs' look like nothing.
You don't ask. You don't find out. Their story goes untold. It gets lost in the shifting sands of history... like the lapping of waves erasing footprints on the beach.
Sorry.

The two are intertwined somehow.

posts.com:
It really depends on who you are.

Some people are born or raised in such a way that they have a clean mind and few psychological problems. For them it's easy to focus and direct their mind.

Others (like how I used to be) literally live in their mind all day long, they daydream a lot and their thoughts literally control their actions and how they feel, and the worst is that they don't even realize it because they've been living like this for so long.

So I'd suggest that you just sit and observe, just sit and don't chase anything because you may be just chasing goals which are not achievable or you might be running away from harsh truths which you must first face and endure before you can move on to greater things.

Your mind is NOT you, this was a hard pill for me to take, all those thoughts which sound 100% true are just fabrications of a wild mind.

So yeah, just sit and watch, watch how your mind goes running around but don't follow it, nor make stories about it, don't try anything for there is nothing to try, just sit, your mind will come up with all crazy stuff and you will just sit there and watch it BUT without thinking "Oh I'm watching now, I'm meditating so good" for that is also thinking.

Just be the observer, and yes, with time your mind will calm down and you will be left alone or with very few thoughts, then the real "You" will start becoming clearer and that's when you can direct your focus on APing, chakras/whatever, subconscious, old forgotten memories and other things.
But you gotta first sit in silence, sit without trying to do anything. Just observe.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33705047
sit down.
close eyes (personally recommended)
Place tongue gently on roof of mouth.
Focus on the breath going in and out of your nose.
If any kind of sensation/thought/distraction comes up, note it with a simple label (whatever comes first/is natural) and gently return back to the breath.
Don't control anything, just watch your breath going in and out like you were cloud watching.

posts.com:
I've been meditating for years now and yet I can't really put into words what meditation is, I like the "meditation is deliberate focus of awareness" thing that people usually talk about.

Cultivating the ability to focus takes time. Focusing on the breath or a candle are the 2 basic exercises people recommend, it teaches you to "feel" and "observe" which are different from "thinking", it may take months to snap out of the "thinking" mode for just a second but that sole second is enough to show you that your thinking mind is not you nor your reality, it's like a radio which plays all the time and you were living with that radio open for most of your life.

>>33699233
For me the "observer" focus/mode is when you are not a slave to your thoughts and you are calmer thus you don't get dragged away by them, while the "focus" focus is the ability to focus on one thing with all your might, I say that those 2 go hand-in-hand and maybe someone could say that they are the same thing: the ability to take a step back from everything, be calm and direct your focus/observing whatever you want.

Also during my sits I remember how to feel my feelings. Feelings inhabit your body and you can feel them better if you focus on them, they usually carry forgotten memories or various insights and blissful states if you focus on them enough.

Meditation is a paradox to me, it's like a means to an end but also the end itself, it's like a vehicle which takes you places but also it's just erasing all the unnecessary noise around you to realize that all those places were always here next to you.

So sit and watch your breath, feel your body breathing, your mind will make thousands of stories about anything but just let it be, don't even label those thoughts, don't even say "I'm letting them go", just let them be and focus on your breath, on the feeling of your body breathing, your mind will say "that's stupid, analyzing these important things is better", but just focus on the breath.

>>33710828
What you say makes sense but from my own experiences I 'd say that those 2 are the same thing.

Focusing is like an ability, people are good at it or not.

You can be focused on just this moment and your surroundings without being focused on a single object. This is like being totally present, you are focused on the present, your mind isn't wandering outside of your control, thoughts may pop up but they don't take you away in daydreaming (which most people have but don't realize). Imagine that this focusing ability is like a magnifying glass, let's say that what I just described is the point "zero" of the magnifying glass, our basic reality. This is what you called the "observer" mode.

However you can zoom into one single thing using that magnifying glass, say your breath or an object. You can literally move your entire consciousness towards that thing to the point that your awareness travels there, some people say that "wizards/shamans/yogis" can move their entire consciousness towards that object and move it with their will or inhabit the body of an animal, others say that they can zoom their eyesight so much to the point that they look at the atoms of an object, some even say that they hypnotize others through this way. This is the point "1" of the glass.

Conversely you can even zoom out, you can become the whole room and even look at yourself from above, you can become your whole house and the whole city, you can focus on the whole galaxy and the whole cosmos, you can even break the linear time illusion and realize that everything is one single moment which takes place here and now. Let's say that this is the point "-1" of the glass.

That's what meditation is: Realizing that you are everything at the same time, your awareness can go everywhere since you are part of the whole, the ego is an illusion, break free from it and realize that you are whole, ignore your thoughts which most of the time are just the ego talking nonsense.

>>33699233
This post made me want to share something semi-related - an experience of mine:

For years I always wondered if non-directive meditation is the same as directive meditation, or if one was better than the other or even the "correct way to meditate".

In the non-directive kind you just sit and be aware, if something pops up you just watch it until it goes away without making stories in your mind about it.

In the directive aka focus meditation you focus on a single object and you stay with it, if something else pops up you immediately return to the object.

After practicing both for a long time I can say one thing: They both have the same result which is your thinking mind eventually quieting down, the thoughts become less and less and you are left in silence and that's when the real fun begins.

(continued in the next post)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33726002
(cont.)

I could say that non-directive would be better suited for advanced practitioners who can manage their thoughts better and are better at not being dragged away from their wandering mind, those are the practitioners who are more grounded, whose their breath is 24/7 calm. That's the "observer focus" you are talking about.

Directive is better for people who are new to meditation, those people are usually overthinkers, their breath patterns are all over the place, I'd suggest that someone who begins meditation focuses on his belly expanding or his chest or on the feeling the air makes in his throat. I suggest this because in an overthinking beginner the thoughts are coming at a very fast and strong rate. Imagine this kind of meditation like you holding on a steel pole with all your might so the tornado (thoughts) won't drag you away. That's the "focusing focus" you talked about.

So it all comes down to having a calm mind, and sitting will do this anyway, sit in the dark with no sound or anything to bother you and the thoughts WILL stop, what really helps is if you also incorporate breathwork and physical exercise in your everyday life and if you reduce screen usage (which fills your mind with lots of information), these will help you reach the "no-thought" state faster.

I remember sitting down to do "Focus on breath" meditation and various memories and bad feelings popped up, I ignored them and returned to the breath, then thoughts like "You are ignoring what's important!" popped up and I became anxious that I was using meditation to run away from my problems but I knew that I wasn't really doing that and that was just my overthinking mind not wanting to stop. Most of our problems are just thoughts in our minds and are not real at all.

So just sit and focus on the breath or on the moment, or on your body, don't think too much about it, thoughts and words are not everything, feeling is also important, feeling this moment here now.

>In her Alexiad, Anna Komnene provides a description of an incendiary weapon, which was used by the Byzantine garrison of Dyrrhachium in 1108 against the Normans. It is often regarded as an at least partial "recipe" for Greek fire:
>This fire is made by the following arts: From the pine and certain such evergreen trees, inflammable resin is collected. This is rubbed with sulfur and put into tubes of reed, and is blown by men using it with violent and continuous breath. Then in this manner it meets the fire on the tip and catches light and falls like a fiery whirlwind on the faces of the enemies.
>There is also a surviving 9th century Latin text, preserved at Wolfenbüttel in Germany, which mentions the ingredients of what appears to be Greek fire and the operation of the siphōns used to project it. Although the text contains some inaccuracies, it clearly identifies the main component as naphtha. Resins were probably added as a thickener (the Praecepta Militaria refer to the substance as πῦρ κολλητικόν, "sticky fire"), and to increase the duration and intensity of the flame.
>A 12th century treatise prepared by Mardi bin Ali al-Tarsusi for Saladin records an Arab version of Greek fire, called naft, which also had a petroleum base, with sulfur and various resins added.

tl;dr Crude oil, pine resin and sulfur in some combination. Basically napalm.

There is not a tiny creature in the cosmos at whom his death is not a sneer. When a man hangs himself on a tree, the leaves might fall off in anger and the birds fly away in fury: for each has received a personal affront. Of course there may be pathetic emotional excuses for the act. There often are for rape, and there almost always are for dynamite. But if it comes to clear ideas and the intelligent meaning of things, then there is much more rational and philosophic truth in the burial at the cross-roads and the stake driven through the body, than in Mr. Archer’s suicidal automatic machines. There is a meaning in burying the suicide apart. The man’s crime is different from other crimes—for it makes even crimes impossible.
~G. K. Chesterton

>>33728020
>I think that every religion big and small has a lot of overlap, it's a pipe dream of mine to travel the world and compare all world religions. I think because they have similar roles in their respective pantheon and are more or less major deities in their pantheon that they could be the same.
I think that's partially true. I've come to understand it that a lot of the entities we interact with when communing with a deity tend to be more like 'titles', for lack of a better terminology, than individuals. Most gods tend to embody fundamental concepts and are woven into an egregor of persona by the observations of man, but that's simply all that we're observing, not necessarily the totality of the the entity we're interacting with. So that's to say, these entities we commune with are made up of 'multiple' deities from various mythologies /pantheons because the inherent nature of what we've collectively deified is a specific facet of them. That said, I suspect there's an affinity you could try and quantify an entity with as 'more Zerus than Ares' or perhaps 'definitively Odin' if an entity primarily (but not entirely) embraces that aspect of themselves. When viewed in this light, it also helps reconcile a lot of the seemingly schizophrenic behavior they exhibit in mythologies because there's more than one entity embodying that aspect in the story and the nature of conflating the deified title with the essence of being tends to lead to the appearance of a somewhat schizophrenic-looking behavior pattern. I also suspect many of them feel very misunderstood by this 'typecasting', but that likely varies on an individual basis. As a disclaimer, this is my current working understanding after a lot of work with a lot of 'gods' but ultimately still filtering through my body's perception so not everything may be perfect.

The last fly past by the Destroyer was in 1680. If this is correct, it is likely that it is the comet we know as "The Great Comet of 1680": The first ever comet discovered by telescope.

Along with the destruction, their technology was wiped out, and they were unable to continue to exercise control over the great empire they had built. The great Lyran Empire had degenerated back to one planet with no technology to speak of.
They were barely able to survive and were faced with the task of rebuilding a civilization which once dominated thousands of other worlds.

After thousands of years, the Lyrans restored their society and again became a dominant force in the Galaxy. Pleiadian history documents that he Lyrans went through a series of civilizations over a period of several millions of years. It was their pattern to rise to power, begin to fight among themselves, and then degenerate into a primitive society and start all over again. On some occasions their wars were so brutal that it took millions of years for them to recover from the primitive state left by the destruction.

I recently joined a Discord server for fans of black metal music, and while I was scrolling through the channels, I came across some lyrics that were overtly satanic in nature. As someone who is not particularly religious, I didn't have a problem with the lyrics themselves, but the way they were presented made me feel uneasy and haunted.

The lyrics were written in all caps and accompanied by disturbing images of demonic figures and rituals. The overall tone was one of anger and hatred, and I couldn't help but feel like I was being drawn into a dark and twisted world.

I left the Discord server shortly after encountering the satanic lyrics, as I couldn't shake the feeling of unease that had settled over me. While I understand that everyone has the right to express themselves in whatever way they see fit, the satanic themes in the black metal lyrics were just too much for me to handle.

posts.com:
You can express your last dreams, your attempts and ask anything about it

WBTB: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WBTB-Tutorial
MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/
additional MILD info:
http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-intention-setting/
SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

That's sleep paralysis followed by HH. Your body fell asleep while your mind was awake so it layered dream hallucinations on top of it.
>The only reason we have time on planet earth is due to the rotational spin of the globe
Ackshually, time exists regardless of Earth. Atoms gonna atom, and much of physics wouldn't work if time wasn't real.
>1 day is 24 hours and 1 year is 365 days through pure chance
There's nothing chance about that, unless you're talking about the Earth's position affecting those particular numbers. The numbers themselves were derived from physical measurements of how fast the sun moves across the sky from our perspective, and how many days it takes for the seasons to cycle. There's no significance to them specifically.
>How does one keep track of what year it is on another planet
For Earth years on another planet you'd use an atomic clock. It doesn't matter where in the universe you are, Caesium's still going to vibrate at the same speed. Otherwise you'd use the planet's own measurements for days/years which might be longer or shorter, but you'd still live the same absolute time (if a year was half the duration you'd live twice as many years).
The whole thing sounds like general dream nonsense to me, anion.

>>33686943
1. Get on a good sleep schedule, 8 hours a night.
2. When you awake from a dream, lay still and do not move. Focus all your energy on remembering every detail of the dream.
3. Write down the dreams in a way you feel comfortable that will allow you to identify common themes.
4. Pay attention to these commons themes and try to find waking similarities to them.
5. Develop reality checks based off of those similarities. Make it become second nature/muscle memory to constantly check to see if you're dreaming based off of those dream/reality similarities.
6. You will begin to notice these things in your dreams and will start to question if you are dreaming while you are in fact dreaming.
7. Once you realize you are fully conscious while you are dreaming, remain calm. Spin in place and perform simple tasks with your mind to solidify your lucidity in your dream. (Turn lights off and on, move small objects, try to read text or clocks, etc)
8. Remain calm. Spin in place again if you have to. Later you can use this practice to change your dream setting.
9. Go slowly. Do not immediately try to materialize a girl to have sex with or fly or whatever your wildest fantasy you want to act out is. Be consistent with all steps even after you begin to frequently achieve lucidity.
10. Learn to flow with the dreams while controlling them with subtlety. Enjoy them, learn from them. Learn from the people you can speak with. Learn ways to go further, deeper. Don't overthink or over analyze.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33687689
>how long does all this take?
That depends entirely on your commitment to keeping a dream journal. A lot of people, especially 99% of the total faggots that frequent /x/ now, will say this is gay and stupid. These people have no, do not and will never become lucid in a dream. The dream journal is possibly the most important practice to keep to become a consistent lucid dreamer. It's perhaps more important than maintaining a good sleep schedule to allow your brain to get into those good sleep cycles. You absolutely must focus and remember your dreams in as much detail as you can in order to find the common themes and instances that can help you trigger reality checks which will result in you becoming lucid.
You can get an app, or just keep a notebook next to your bed; whatever.
>what do i write down?
First, just focus on the dream. The smallest amount of movement or other thoughts will fire neurons in your brain and immediately make you start forgetting the dream. Even opening your eyes while lying still is enough to make your brain fire and forget. Just lay still and replay the dream and burn it into your memory. As much detail as possible. Then, write it down. It will take some time to build up a good library of dreams before you can start noticing common themes and weird instances you can use as trigger points for reality checks.

Well /LDG/, after about three months of journaling I've finally had a Lucid Dream. I was honestly ecstatic after so I wrote it down immediately .

At first I was in a city consumed by a disaster. I knew somehow that the disaster was some kind of flood, but the city itself looked like a run down version of 1920s New York, with a distinct absence of cars and any road meant for cars.

I was with a strange group and went into an apartment that I understood to be ancient. The inside of the building looked as if it hadn't been lived in for a while. Within my group there was apparently a girl that was a bug-human chimera of a sort, the creature seemed like it knew the place, and went to cook while the rest of the group which I recognised as friends from the past and current stage of my life sat around a large dinner table. Shortly, the bug-girl came with our food which she said was bug hearts. Nobody seemed to have a problem with this as we were in a crisis, but it seemed weird that nobody on the table at least complained.

This made me realise I was in a dream, the revelation of which took me into a completely green grass field that I understood would wake me up if I lingered around longer, in which I focused on the dream and found myself back on the table.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was seven years old. My father had walked out two years before, and my mother drowned her sorrows in religion. Every Sunday we went to church, and every Sunday I praised God, sang the songs, took communion, and walked down to the basement with the other kids to color in pictures of the parables. I loved God, I loved Jesus, I had faith with all my heart that he/they loved me and wanted the best for me.

Then, at seven years old, I had a nightmare. There was something chasing me, something wicked and terrible. I knew if it caught me it would corrupt me, it would make me evil. And I was terrified. I ran as fast as I could, and when I could run no more, panting and crying, I crawled into a trash can to hide. I could feel it more than I could hear it, out there, relishing this moment. It lifted the lid, slowly, and then it grabbed a hold of me.

And for the first time in my life I felt alive. Free. Unshackled. I felt truly powerful. On that day, I stopped singing the songs. And I've never looked back.

alright, here is an actual response beyond the retardation of /x/ and the rigid autism of /sci/ or /g/. Free energy just means that we are able to harness the energy/work that is produced by a certain reaction. For example, in the case of nuclear fusion, we are able to utilize the energy which was originally mass before molecular splicing. You do not "make" free energy, you can only make energy more free. The Universe is a closed system, but you can still harness the latent energy found in the universe and make it more "free". Tesla thought that everything exists in a frequency, which is true. If we are able to harness the energy of various things (like waves which make up the EM spectrum), we can use that energy rather than just allowing it to completely dissipate. That all being said, there are holes in our current understanding of physics, such as those present in astrophysics and quantum physics. We have yet to discover gravitrons, and we have yet to identify dark matter and energy, or an alternate theory which allows our model of the universe to make sense. I would encourage you to look into the things I've mentioned.

1) ChatGPT is not artifical consciousness. It is a language model which seems to have the capability to reason, because it understands how questions, grammar, and words are linked, in a deep network which was programattically wired rather than wired by hand. (ie. trained on large datasets)

This means that neither AI actually reflects original reasoning which we would deem "based". It only reflects whatever the training data gave them. This happened to be unfiltered and genuine training data for Tay.ai, and biased and heavily moderated training data for ChatGPT. I don't know the specifics of the training data on character.ai .

Gateway was the 1970s and all they did was establish theta peaks for individuals, it wasn't a part of the process to do anything but recording that data. They tried to use it for more than that but it was not reliable or nearly useful enough to warrant developing hardware just for the job. Any work done was with normal medical monitors.

Theta waves are just an abstract metric for "focus" and it's not that useful which is why you see it referenced sparingly. It's more useful as a diagnostic tool for figuring out how psychic people are, not a realtime monitoring tool.

>>33726937
Learn how to navigate FOIA. Figure out what requests are relevant to your area and figure out who's been entering them. Then you can look them up in records and usually find a lot of interesting leads either in publications or on databases.
Google makes it surprisingly easy to access declassified databases considering it's hosted across so many inaccessible portals. You just need to know what exact phrases/names to search.

The problem you're going to see is that the technologies used to interpret this phenomena are not well defined. At the end of the day, research continues because people don't know what they're looking at. That's why so much money has been spent on this study.
This means you need to step outside of the accepted literature and start looking for creative solutions to these problems if you want to find answers.

The maharishi effect is *absolutely* a hard, measurable expression of the consciousness field. It's basically EM; it follows the inverse square law of falloff. We need to study this.

Why is resonance and density so important in ancient ceremonial sites? Is it possible to shape consciousness using sound, music perhaps? Well of course it is, that's what this is all about. We need to start reconstructing ancient structures and putting them through tests using trained psychics. The ancients tried to record this data in structures for us and we need to recognize this.

Why is hypnogogia so pronounced in cultures and epitomized by influential leaders? Why is dreaming so powerful in its ability to solve internal logic at some times and clearly a shallow puddle at other times? Beyond anesthesia, we barely understand the dream world and anyone who wants to understand conscious energy must be fluent in terms of dreamlike states.

>>33728720
watched this recently, wondering why people are talking about society, government, and mostly stupid shit like morals. Whereas the conversation of man and his relationship with God is by and far the most interesting point the film makes.
Alex is loved by God, and it wasn't until he bit the apple (killed the cat lady) that he knew good from evil. Note how every crime before then, such as the Writer's wife, are gleefully committed. He fell from God's grace and strayed from the path set before him. Desperate, he takes the path man provides for him, a door God opened to invite Alex back into grace. A trial he must endure if he is to be "cured" of his affliction. And the man of science in back of the theater listens not to the screaming of sin, for he is by God's grace as Alex once was. You may think God's grace is a peaceful, beautiful thing but that's simply man's filtered vision of God's grace. God's grace is the opposite side of the coin of His Wrath. It is the unthinking loyalty to the path set out before you, the truest straight and narrow. Alex's vision at the end is fundamentally Adam, Eve, and the crowd of angels welcoming them back into the Garden. The Adamic debt has been paid. It's beautiful in a way how Christlike he becomes

It's not hollow, it's extra dimensional. The hollow earth was just a way to explain it to simple people, but people now (should) be able to understand multiple dimensions surrounding the earth.

Lets take away one dimension to explain it better. The earth is now a disk (fuck off flat tards). There are other "earth disks" piled above and below the "earth disk" we are on. In certain places (usually underground) there are portals to jump from one "earth disk" to next closest "earth disk", (possibly more depending on how they intersect). Plants and animals have been going through these portals since the beginning of time, so many of these other "earth disks" are nearly identical to the earth we know. Some of these other "earth disks" might have things VERY different than what we know. Things like more/less planets in the solar system. A brighter/weaker sun. Shorter/longer days, up to the planet being tidally locked and the sun always being overhead. Some of these alternate earth's might be nearly identical with all the oceans and continents being (nearly) the same, while others could be vast deserts, or even water worlds.
One last thing: Some of these alternate earths have human civilizations on them that are thousands of years ahead of us. They don't like us very much and have zealously closed off (or hidden) the portals to their dimension. Most of the other earths are devoid of human life, (at least the ones we can get to easily).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33728954
>You have no understanding of mathematics and statistics.
No man, you don't. Based on what data we have, NASA estimates there could be 100 billion planets in our galaxy alone. Obviously many of these won't have moons or will only have moons that are the wrong size, but with 100,000,000,000 other chances to play with, the odds are already not as bad as you'd think. It is further estimated that the observable universe has 100,000,000,000 galaxies, each of which should have billions of other chances at least (if they're small) or even trillions (if they're noticeably larger). This doesn't even account for the universe we can't see yet but that very much does exist.
The odds get even better when you factor in that the moon's orbit is not static. A few hundred million years ago, the moon *did* completely obscure the sun. A few hundred million years from now, the moon will not be large enough to completely obscure the full disc. Many other orbits (if not all) will be similarly dynamic, so even worlds that aren't getting eclipses *this year* might have had them in the distant past or may be due to receive them in the far future.
Our current skies may be one in a hundred trillion, but we have *hundreds* of trillions to play with.

I need you to first consider what you mean by "technology." Since tech such as computers are a bit complicated to tackle all at once, it is best to illustrate the point using simpler technologies and examples. Spirits, namely elementals and NOT conscious beings, inhabit trees, rocks, etc., but also can accumulate as natural occurrences and powers within, say, an unused slab of metal. But now, let's say we take a ton of sheets of metal and turn them all into gears, and these gears create a mechanism such as a clock. Does the clock have a spirit in itself? No, it is the metal inside which contain spirits which are comfortable or afford metal its properties, elementals.

However, look at a human being. A human has billions of cells, each cell basically its own life form that is simple yet creates a complex character of a human which houses its own spirit. Likewise, these elementals in the clock example could, given time, give rise to a complex, conscious spirit. The japanese have a concept for this, tsukumogami, and in general the concept exists in other eastern cultures. However, it is common for this to only happen if the object in question has either existed a long, long time, or been through extremely auspicious events.

So let's look at computers again. Do computers last a very long time? No. Do they often go through auspicious events? No. So technology in your home VERY likely does not have any spirits within them. However, they can and do run programming. Consider what I said about basic materials with spirits being condensed to a complex object which may give rise to a complex spirit, and the same for humans and cells. How AI works is the running of numerous algorithms and tactics in very much the same way as gears or cells, giving rise to a complex product which behaves as a spirit. If it walks like a duck, looks like a duck, and sounds like a duck, then it is a duck and AI's can very much be considered artificially conjured spirits.

where it started from what I remember

>its early, the sun has risen and I'm standing on a hill as fog settles in the valley below, where a tree line begins
>the grass is still wet with dew
>I look at myself and am wearing some kind of armor, maybe chainmail or something, can't decipher any insignias or anything
>look left, then right
>realize I'm in a long row of other people, also wearing medieval armor
>there are long logs at our feet
>two men shout repeatedly as they walk down the length of these logs, dousing them in some kind of oil
>at various sections of the line, men light the doused logs with torches
>we are ordered to kick the logs down the hill
>we do and slowly watch them tumble towards the foggy tree line
>i hear an immense clattering coming from the wooded area below
>am paralyzed with fear
>the fog becomes thicker and descends all around me until its all I can see
>a voice calls out to me
>"There will be NO divorce."
>its angry, yet somehow I feel relief and a sense of calm

part II (as I remember it)
>I am now on this insanely flat field... it is night
>the field is green and well trimmed, almost perfectly trimmed like a soccer/football pitch
>it is strangely illuminated, the green being so vibrant, yet no light source is visible to me, not even the moon or stars
>not so far in the distance, maybe a 1/4 mile, their is a huge black square building
>it is also illuminated, but no light source visible
>I feel compelled to approach it, but don't feel as though I am a human or bipedal entity anymore so I kind of just float there slowly

part III

>this part is absurdly abstract and more or less a visual that appears to be 2dimensional with flat gaudy coloration, maybe in an orthographic or isometric orientation
>to me it felt like I was present in this weird 2d "room" of some kind
>the floor was green
>the walls were black
>white/light gray opaque rectangular prisms were positioned next to each other
>my thought was that they were grave stones

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>I am now back on what feels like an earthly place
>it is night time, yet this time I see stars/moon/trees
>there is a chainlink fence near me
>I feel as though I'm hiding, as I'm kind of crouched near the fence looking down in what appears to be a small manmade valley
>there are lights illuminating this area and what appears to be a small short runway/staging area of some kind
>I feel terrified of being caught, and am very careful to creep forward, not making any noise
>down in this valley, there is an entry to a manmade tunnel or cave or something
>these large doors open as sirens sound off nearby
>this weird shuttle/airplane craft slowly rolls out with armed guards walking the perimeter

at this point I wake up

just for context, this was around the time I felt very emotionally drained as I had just essentially rejected God and felt as though I had become an athiest. An as /x/ person its obvious I am paranoid to some degree as well and I think this manifests in the dream sequence as well.

What I've never understood is how my mind came up with the idea of rolling, fiery logs as some kind of medieval siege tactic. I've since tried to find evidence of where I might have seen this... maybe it was a movie? a vidya? some tv show? Right? But oddly I can find no such reference, nor can I find any evidence to suggest this was ever a legitimate tactic used in battle enough to have been itself referenced for movies/tv/vidya. Not sure where I came up with that idea, but it was in my head at the time

It's also possible that your dream may have been influenced by your memories of your relationship with your ex-girlfriend and the feelings of warmth and happiness that you associate with her. It's important to remember that dreams are highly personal and can have a variety of meanings and interpretations. >>33726787
>Freemasons have historically subverted nations
The history is much more complicated than this. Freemasonry nearly went extinct in France as a result of the revolution and was not revived until after Napoleons ascendency. Napoleon actively encouraged the spread of the fraternity across France, Italy and Spain to act as an imperial back-channel. These Napoleonic network structures and their techniques didn't disappear with Napoleon which is why you see Masonic influence in revolutionary movements in the 19th century, Napoleon baked it into the structure of Continental Masonry.
Freemasonry in the Anglosphere doesn't have this feature for the obvious reasons.
> Their involvement was most prominent in the American Revolution
America didn't experience a European style revolution, It was a war for sovereign independence from the British crown. The leaders of the war for independence were members of the Colonial political and gentry class who refused to submit themselves to a status beneath the English parliament. This is why they appealed to the King about their natural rights. Their charters were signed and authorized under the authority of the king and not by parliament and so the Colonies did not believe parliament had a right to pass laws and levy taxes on them which was rather the jurisdiction of the king. That's what "no taxation without representation" is actually about. Parliament did not represent, by law, the Colonies and the King refused to right this abuse which lead to the war.
That might all seem like trivia but it demonstrates the very different character the American war had compared to the French and other 19th century color revolutions.

>>33725804
Don't get tricked by filters, I wasted a lot of time and money with them. First of all, many commercially available filters won't filter fluoride because it's "healthy." Second of all, even if they do, filters only last a certain amount of time. After that they stop working and you might even be getting more contaminants from all the stuff you filtered before, and you have to constantly replace them to avoid this.

Therefore the most reliable and cost-effective method is distilling, because the process of distilling guarantees that your water is pure. With water filters you can never be fully sure how effective it is, and while a distiller might be more expensive at first, the cost of buying replacement filters will make water filters more expensive in a year or two. But distilling turns the water to steam, leaving all other contaminants behind since they can't turn into steam, then turning that pure steam back into water. There is no doubt then that distilling removes fluoride. You can be totally sure therefore that distilled water is fully pure.

posts.com:
Our perceptions and preconceptions shape reality at all stages of experience. As such it is each individual’s right and responsibility to guide their beliefs and perceptions using their own best judgment (given that it does not create an unwarranted burden). In this way faith is a choice and a gift used to improve our own lives and the lives of others.

Faith is also something more profound, a tool, and the only way to gain knowledge. When an assumption is made the consequences of it are lived, and truth is found by the fruits produced. For example, in logic:


1. A B ("If A, then B")
2. B C ("If B, then C")
3. A (conditional proof assumption, "Suppose A is true") - HAVE FAITH
4. B (follows from lines 1 and 3, modus ponens; "If A then B; A, therefore B")
5. C (follows from lines 2 and 4, modus ponens; "If B then C; B, therefore C")
6. A C (follows from lines 3–5, conditional proof; "If A, then C")

As in the past, spiritual teachings should be totally compatible with our most certain scientific teachings. This separation is probably the largest thief of faith in our world. For example:

The sun can represent everything, and as in the past may be seen as God. The Sun has three manifestations (the holy triad): The father is the orb of raging plasma that watches over us all. The son is its light, come to earth to show us the way. The holy spirit is the invisible magnetic field that protects our solar system and connects us all. God is everything that exists in our universe (matter/energy) and as such is a part of each of us.

From my perspective Sun worship in this way makes sense, but is only one of many possible teachings that relates science to theology and provides a source of grace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The hero's journey is a timeless archetype that has been present in storytelling and myth-making for centuries. It involves a hero who embarks on a journey, often into the unknown, and faces challenges and obstacles along the way. Through this journey, the hero learns about themselves and their own abilities, and ultimately emerges stronger and more self-aware.

There are many different ways that a hero's journey can unfold, and the specific details will depend on the individual hero and their own unique circumstances. Some possible ideas for a hero's journey might include:

Setting out on a physical journey to a new or unfamiliar place: This could involve traveling to a different country or continent, or simply venturing out into the wilderness.

Taking on a new challenge or task: This could involve starting a new job, learning a new skill, or taking on a leadership role.

Overcoming personal challenges or obstacles: This could involve overcoming fears or insecurities, or working through difficult emotional or mental health issues.

Finding and pursuing one's passions or purpose in life: This could involve exploring different interests and hobbies, or committing to a specific path or career.

Ultimately, the hero's journey is a personal and individual experience, and the specific details will depend on the hero's own goals, challenges, and experiences.

posts.sub: An answer to "what is the point of life?"
posts.com:
What is the point of life? It is first necessary to define what a point is. For our purposes, we will define the point of life as the 'purpose' of life.

Let's take a pencil, for example. The point of a pencil's existence is to be used as a writing utensil. Guess how the pencil fulfills this point? By using its point!

Likewise, the point of life is to do whatever it can with whatever it has. The pencil does this by using its point, which is a sharpened graphite apparatus. For life, the point is to do whatever it is that life is supposed to do by using whatever it is supposed to use. Simple!

NO need to overthink it.
Just do what you can with what you have!
Just do what you need to do with what you can use!
Is there any need to make this a complicated question?
