>>33718692
We have no idea how language originated from a linguistics perspective. Unless you believe the world is younger than recorded history or at least within the realms of reconstruction (likely no older than 12,000 years for some families) we have no idea. There is no trace we can break down from the data available to us to even hope recreating a language from 20,000 years ago, let alone the original human tongue. That is if there is one, it’s equally possible that language begins in many points across time in different groups, we guess it arrived with modern humans but it could be older and common to homonids in general. Human children essentially cannot learn a language if they are not exposed to at least one as a youth. How it organically sprung up is beyond us, it could have come from a sign language first, it could have come from people imitating animals, it could be from god or aliens, it could have organically sprung up as a complex system. We have no idea, it is so ancient we will likely never know unless we perform some immoral experiments by isolating children from language at birth and raising them in a social group together. I believe we have evidence of sign languages organically springing up from groups of deaf children which is fascinating though.

All we know is the human brain is wired to understand and express human language. It is hardwired into us and we can take a baby, let people talk at it and it will intuitively work out the entire system, including potentially insanely complex intricacies such as 20+ case systems, huge tonal systems, consonant mutations etc… that fuck the head of an adult trying to learn them. If you took a group of human babies and left them with no exposure to language, my best guess is that it would form organically over generations. We seem to be coded to work this shit out.

posts.com:
>ITT: anons post pictures of trips to cemeteries and interesting paranormal sites

Welcome to Grave /x/plorers General

Post photos of your local cemeteries and paranormal sites. A few suggestions though:

1) Respect the dead. Don't step/lean on markers. Try to pick up trash whenever possible. If its close to a marker assume its an offering and leave it be. It should go without saying, don't take anything. It belongs to the deceased and it is punishable by imprisonment.
2) Respect the living. People are grieving, don't take photos of them intentionally. If a mourner approaches, put the camera down and clear out. Come back later if you wish after they are gone.
3) Do not trespass. Its locked for a reason. Keep out.
4) Do not destroy or break anything in an attempt to gain access/take a photo. Maintenance crews will find out and lock down the area which will ruin it for future investigators.

Use your best judgement as a rule of thumb

Some recommendations:

1) Boots and old/rugged clothes. You might be climbing fences and walking through muddy areas. Don't wear anything you're not ready to get soiled or tear.
2) Tripod. It makes for taking excellent panning shots, still videos and self photos.
3) Water. Running around a cemetery all morning is cause for dehydration. Maybe a light snack.
4) Get there as soon as it opens. In the early morning there are few to no people which will be best for photographs and not to inconvenience anyone.
5) Take photos of weird and interesting things you notice. Report back

>But I dont have any paranormal sites or graveyards in my area

The potential for the paranormal to exist is everywhere. Even if its tied to your cities history like an accident or tragedy, or a long walk innawoods alone, youre bound to find something /x/ related

Previous thread: https://archive.4plebs.org/x/thread/33685301/#33685301

Have fun

>Something to keep in mind so you don't end up with a thread full of upside down or sideways photos:

+ 4chan(nel) strips .exif

Another solution: Always take video and photographs in the horizontal mode of your camera phone

posts.com: I'm not certain about the definition in a Christian context, but Aristotle used this concept a lot. Baiscally, prima materia is matter but abstract, because it has no form (i.e. essence, or specificities). It cannot exist by itself because it's only the second term in things (essence/substance). It's the passive principle which contains virtually every material possibility, but which has to be "opened up".

>>33723194
It depends on what you mean by "idea". From a platonic point of view ("platonic ideas"), essences exist by themselves, without their material manifestations: they are principles of the material realm. Aristotle was actually against Plato's doctrine of ideas, but still believed that essence were defined (though they didn't exist in the spiritual realm).If you want to understand this doctrine, I suggest you to read Plato's Phaedo. He never exposes this doctrine in full, but it sums it up. For example, beautiful material things are only beautiful as in so for ar they are linked to the Idea (Form/Essance) of Beauty.

The Prima Materia -is- the Quitessece/Aether, and is also connected to the Anima Mundi in western Christianity since the late middle ages.
By the way a 'Christian Hermeticism' as envisioned in that book does not exist, what does exist however is the influence Hermetism had on Christianity, during the middle ages saints like Albertus Magnus developed cosmologies based on their knowledge of arabic translations of hermetic texts (only the 'technical' kind dealing with alchemy, magic and astrology, the 'religious' kind both existed beforehand in Latin, the Ascelpius, and the Corpus Have got translated at the beginning of the Renaissance by Marsilio Ficino from Greek but it's influence never really went anywhere in the Church) and of neoplatonic ones, particularly the cosmology of Liber de Causis
Overall it's a good book, especially good as something introductory as it's a form of 'Catholic Sophiology' (Sophiology is an Eastern Orthodox movement) mixed in with more 'Occult' speech to get people who are into that get interested in becoming Catholic, but if you want to go deeper i suggest you delve into:
>Jakob Böhme (Protestant)
>Nicholas of Cusa (Catholic)
>Sergei Bulgakov (Orthodox)
And from there you can expand through studying their influences and who they influenced

>The Prima Materia -is- the Quitessece/Aether, and is also connected to the Anima Mundi in western Christianity since the late middle ages.
Mind elaborating if you have the spare time? How can the first element also be the fifth element? How does the Anima Mundi get involved here?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33727029
Sure,
Basically during medieval times the Aristotelian concept of the 5 elements mixed with the Neoplatonic Cosmogony and was used as the framework for why things like Astrology, Alchemy and Magic worked.
First of all Aristotle, basing himself on the philosophy that came before him, wrote that our world (planet earth) was composed of 4 Elements, but those 4 came from a single Element called Aether which Aristotle belived was the Element the 7 Classical Planets were made out of.
In Neoplatonism the Unknowable God, called One/Monad, emanates/'overflows' into Nous (meaning Intellect, but it has a more complex meaning) which you can interpret as the 'Knowable God', then the Anima Mundi (World Soul) and then from the Anima overflows material reality.
Now during medieval times those mixed together as material reality was belived to be composed of 4 unchanging elements, since the origin of our world originates from Anima Mundi that'd mean that the Anima is that 5th unchanging Element.
